Package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost

Interface InHostPhenomenologicalState

All Superinterfaces:
InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel>, Serializable
@Immutable public interface InHostPhenomenologicalState extends InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel>
A phenomenological in-host model that tracks viral load and immune activity over time, supporting multiple exposures (e.g., reinfection or vaccination).

The model uses a biphasic logistic function to describe the rise and fall of viral load and immune response following each exposure. It supports superposition of multiple exposure events, where each contributes independently to the overall viral load and immunity.

The total viral load is computed as the complementary probability of no viral presence from any exposure: \[ V(t) = 1 - \prod_{e \in \text{exposures}} \left(1 - v_e(t)\right) \] where \( v_e(t) \) is the viral load contribution from exposure \( e \), modeled using a shifted biphasic logistic curve. This formulation assumes independent contributions and corresponds to the probability that at least one exposure is active at time \( t \).

Similarly, immune activity is aggregated as: \[ I(t) = 1 - \prod_{e \in \text{exposures}} \left(1 - i_e(t)\right) \] where \( i_e(t) \) is the immune response triggered by exposure \( e \).

This approach naturally captures:

  • Boosting of immunity from repeated exposures,
  • Sub-threshold infections that contribute to immunity without causing disease,
  • Waning immunity over time.

The model is parameterized using observable clinical features (onset time, peak delay, etc.) and calibrated via logistic regression on key points of the curve.

See Also:

  • InHostPhenomenologicalState.BiPhasicLogistic

    Methods inherited from interface io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost.InHostModelState

    update

  • Method Details

    • getExposures

      @Redacted List<InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel> getExposures()
      Returns the list of exposures that have occurred up to the current time. Each exposure is represented by an InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel that captures its timing, dose and immune context. The list is used to compute the overall viral load and immune activity by aggregating contributions from all exposures.
      Returns:
      a list of exposure models representing past infection or vaccination events

    • getImmuneActivity

      @Derived default double getImmuneActivity()
      Computes the total immune activity at the current time by aggregating responses from all prior exposures.

      Similar to viral load, immune activity is modeled as: \[ I(t) = 1 - \prod_{e} \left(1 - i_e(t)\right) \] where \( i_e(t) \) is the immune response from exposure \( e \), modeled using a logistic growth and decay process. This captures immune boosting and partial protection from sub-infectious doses.

      The immune response is not reset by new infections; instead, it accumulates, reflecting immunological memory.

      Specified by:
      getImmuneActivity in interface InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel>
      Returns:
      the combined immune activity at the current time, in normalized units

    • getImmunityModel

      InHostPhenomenologicalState.BiPhasicLogistic getImmunityModel()
      Returns the biphasic logistic model used to compute immune response dynamics. This model is similarly calibrated and defines the shape of the immune response curve following each exposure. It is used by the InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel to compute the immune activity contribution of each exposure at any given time.
      Returns:
      the biphasic logistic model for immune response dynamics

    • getInfectiousnessCutoff

      double getInfectiousnessCutoff()
      Returns the viral load threshold above which the person is considered infectious. This cutoff is used to normalize the viral load and to determine infectiousness in transmission models.
      Returns:
      the viral load cutoff for infectiousness

    • getNormalisedSeverity

      default double getNormalisedSeverity()
      Computes a proxy for disease severity as the maximum viral load across all active exposures.

      In this phenomenological model, severity is assumed to be driven by the peak viral load from any single exposure event: \[ S(t) = \max_{e} v_e(t) \] This reflects the idea that clinical outcomes are dominated by the most severe infection event, even in the presence of multiple exposures.

      Specified by:
      getNormalisedSeverity in interface InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel>
      Returns:
      the highest viral load contribution from any single exposure at current time

    • getNormalisedViralLoad

      default double getNormalisedViralLoad()
      Returns the viral load normalized relative to the infectiousness cutoff.

      The normalization is defined as: \[ V_{\text{norm}}(t) = \frac{V(t)}{V_{\text{cutoff}}} \] where \( V_{\text{cutoff}} \) is the minimum viral load required for infectiousness. This ratio is used in transmission models to compute transmissibility.

      Specified by:
      getNormalisedViralLoad in interface InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel>
      Returns:
      normalized viral load relative to the infectiousness threshold

    • getTime

      int getTime()
      Returns the current time step in the in-host model. Time is measured in discrete units (e.g., days) since the start of the infection or simulation.
      Specified by:
      getTime in interface InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel>
      Returns:
      the current time step

    • getViralLoad

      @Derived default double getViralLoad()
      Computes the total viral load at the current time step by combining contributions from all prior exposures using probabilistic superposition.

      Each exposure \( e \) contributes a viral load curve \( v_e(t) \), which is zero before the exposure time and follows a biphasic logistic function afterward. The overall viral load is computed as the complement of the probability that none of the exposures are active: \[ V(t) = 1 - \prod_{e} \left(1 - v_e(t)\right) \] This formulation assumes independence between exposure events and corresponds to the union of their individual effects.

      Returns:
      the combined viral load at the current time, in normalized units

    • getViralLoadModel

      InHostPhenomenologicalState.BiPhasicLogistic getViralLoadModel()
      Returns the biphasic logistic model used to compute viral load dynamics. This model is calibrated from clinical parameters and defines the shape of the viral load curve following each exposure. It is used by the InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel to compute the viral load contribution of each exposure at any given time.
      Returns:
      the biphasic logistic model for viral load dynamics

    • update

      default InHostPhenomenologicalState update(Sampler sampler, double virionDose, double immunisationDose)
      Advances the in-host state by one time step, updating exposures and immune/viral dynamics.

      The update process:

      1. Removes exposures that are no longer relevant (immune response has waned below 1%),
      2. Processes a new exposure (if any), scaling the initial viral dose by host susceptibility,
      3. Creates a new InHostPhenomenologicalState.ExposureModel with appropriate growth and decay offsets,
      4. Increments the time counter.

      The new exposure's initial viral load is: \[ v_0 = \text{Conversions.scaleProbabilityByRR}(V_{\text{cutoff}}, \text{virionDose}) \] which adjusts the baseline infectious dose by the exposure intensity.

      Specified by:
      update in interface InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel>
      Parameters:
      sampler - unused in this deterministic model (reserved for stochastic extensions)
      virionDose - the magnitude of new viral exposure (relative to infectious dose)
      immunisationDose - currently unused; reserved for explicit vaccine modeling
      Returns:
      a new state advanced by one time unit with updated exposures
